prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
To estimate the intensities of the proposed H2CO transitions towards Arp220 we consider the following:
-- Mangum etal (2013a) derive (log(n(H2)), log(N(orth-H2CO)/Deltav)) > (5.00,12.85) for an NH3-derived TK > 180 K (Mangum etal 2013b).
-- The measured dense gas source sizes of the two nuclei within the starburst nuclear region of Arp220 are ~0.8 arcsec, with a largest angular size to the dense gas of ~2 arcsec (Sakamoto etal (2008).
-- Figure 2 summarizes our GBT (theta_B = 51 and 153 arcsec), IRAM 30m (theta_B = 11 to 20 arcsec), and VLA (theta_B = 6 arcsec) measurements of the H2CO emission toward Arp220. All of these H2CO transitions have peak intensities of 4--5 mK (GBT and IRAM 30m) and 300 mK (VLA).
-- Predicted intensities based on LVG modeling for the proposed transitions (i.e. the intensities used to produce Fig. 1) scaled to our single-dish GBT measurements range from 0.5 to 1.0 K. Note that this estimate does not include the H213CO 3(12)-2(11) transition as it is measured for "free" using an unallocated baseband (B6-4), and will give us an estimate of the H2CO optical depth.
-- By comparing the H2CO 1(10)-1(11) single-dish (GBT; 4 mK in theta_B = 51 arcsec; Mangum etal 2013a; Fig. 2) and interferometer (VLA; 300 mK in theta_B = 6 arcsec; Mangum etal 2014; Fig. 2) measurements we can determine an approximate scaling from our single-dish H2CO measurements to the predicted ALMA intensities. If we allow for emission on scales to which we are sensitive (theta_s ~ 3 arcsec), and conservatively allow that only ~25% of the single-dish emission contributes to these high-spatial frequency structures, our measured and predicted single-dish H2CO intensities should be scaled by a factor of >100.
-- FWZI for most molecular line measurements of Arp220, including our H2CO measurements, is ~500 km/s.
Taking these factors into account we conservatively predict peak H2CO line intensities of at least 50 K. As 10:1 signal-to-noise results in a time request that is almost completely dominated by overhead, we request a sensitivity limit of 0.25 K (0.8 mJy at 218 GHz) at the expense of an additional 15 minutes of on-source integration time.
Our proposed observing setup will utilize theta_B = 0.3 arcsec at Band 6. The theta_{las} =~ 3.0 arcsec at both bands will sample all of the dense gas emission from the dual starburst nuclei in Arp220. Our correlator configuration parameters have been designed for maximum line measurement efficiency:
(1) BW = 1875 MHz within each spectral window noted in Table 1.
(2) Channel spacing of ~15 km/s at Band 6 (after smoothing).
These observing parameters will allow us to spatially and spectrally characterize the dense gas kinetic temperature within the starburst nuclei and their interaction environment.
Line Overlap Considerations
The predicted FWZI/FWHM linewidth is ~500/200 km/s (~700/280 MHz), while our spectral resolution will be 7.8 MHz (smoothed to 10.9 MHz or 15 km/s). The 3(03)-2(02)/3(22)-2(21) transitions will be partially blended. As the 3(21)-2(20) transition is the spectral "twin" (equivalent predicted intensity) to the 3(22)-2(21) transition, we will apply the measured spectral characteristics of the unblended 3(21)-2(20) transition to the spectral deconvolution of the 3(22)-2(21) transition.
A search for potential "interloper" molecular species, where we used the 1.3 mm survey of Arp 220 by Martin etal (2011) and our IRAM 30m measurements as a guide, uncovered several line overlaps
(1) CH3OH 4(2,2)-3(12) at 218.44 GHz and HC3N 24-23 at 218.325 GHz overlap with our H2CO 3(03)-2(02)/3(22)-2(21) measurements. We anticipate being able to spectrally and spatially deconvolve these potential interlopers using our other H2CO unblended line measurements.
(2) 13CO 2-1 at 220.399 GHz and C18O 2-1 at 219.56 GHz are included in the baseband for our H2C13CO 3(12)-2(11) measurement. These transitions are ~400 MHz away from our H213CO transition so are minimally blended.

-- Mangum etal (2013a) derive (log(n(H2)), log(N(orth-H2CO)/Deltav)) > (5.00,12.85) for an NH3-derived TK > 180 K (Mangum etal 2013b).

-- Predicted intensities based on LVG modeling for the proposed transitions (i.e. the intensities used to produce Fig. 1) scaled to our single-dish GBT measurements range from 10 to 500 mK.
-- By comparing the H2CO 1(10)-1(11) single-dish (GBT; 4 mK in theta_B = 51 arcsec; Mangum etal 2013a; Fig. 2) and interferometer (VLA; 300 mK in theta_B = 6 arcsec; Mangum etal 2014; Fig. 2) measurements we can determine an approximate scaling from our single-dish H2CO measurements to the predicted ALMA intensities. Taking these factors into account we conservatively predict peak H2CO line intensities of at least 3 K. As 10:1 signal-to-noise results in a time request that is almost completely dominated by overhead, we request a sensitivity limit of 0.15 K (1.3 mJy at 345 GHz) at the expense of an additional 15 minutes of on-source integration time.

We have also chosen our spectral line configurations to minimize overlap by both nearby H2CO transitions and "interloper" molecular species. The predicted FWZI/FWHM linewidth is ~500/220 km/s (~600/270 MHz), while our spectral resolution will be 7.8 MHz (smoothed to 18.3 MHz or 15 km/s). The following transitions will be at least partially (<~ FWHM) blended (see Table 1):
(1) The "twin" transition pairs 5(42)-4(41)/5(41)-4(40) and 5(33)-4(32)/5(32)-4(31). Both of these transition pairs have identical predicted intensities.
(2) 5(24)-4(23)/5(4)-4(4) are separated by 157 MHz, which is ~50% of the predicted FWHM linewidth. As the 5(23)-4(22) transition is the spectral "twin" (equivalent predicted intensity) to the 5(24)-4(23) transition, we will apply the measured spectral characteristics of the unblended 5(23)-4(22) transition to the spectral deconvolution of the 5(24)-4(23) transition.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: A characterization of the physical properties of the dense gas within the interstellar medium of starburst galaxies is critical to our understanding of their evolution. Many of the molecular tracers used to characterize the dense gas in star-forming galaxies suffer from a coupled degenerate sensitivity to the kinetic temperature and volume density. A molecular tracer which can decouple individual physical conditions is required. Results from a survey of a sample of active star-forming galaxies has shown that Formaldehyde (H2CO) is a reliable and accurate density probe for extragalactic environments where the kinetic temperature is known. Ammonia (NH3) is a traditional probe of the kinetic temperature in dense gas environments, but its utility requires an assumption of cospatiality between dense gas tracers is required. Using the unique sensitivities to kinetic temperature afforded by the excitation characteristics of several transitions of H2CO, we propose to continue our characterization of the dense gas in galaxies exhibiting starbursts by imaging the gas kinetic temperature in a representative pilot sample of three starburst galaxies: Arp220, NGC253, and NGC4945.
